Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Set out with the intention of digging a pit in a location representative of our Ritchie's Rocks slide path. Upon reaching the area we felt safe digging in the actual slide path thanks to numerous anchors and a shallow snow pack. We were looking to see if our two PWLs, the November early season facets and the January 4th crust/facet combo still existed in this area. The crust from the January 4 layers still exists but the facets both above and below have rounded out. The basal facets still exist but are not continuous. Where snow lies on dirt, the basal facets have rounded out, where snow fell on rocks the basal facets still exist. An additional melt/freeze crust was found at this location 35cm up in the snow pack with near crust faceting below it. All of these layers are capped by a strong melt/freeze crust from the most recent warm spell.

Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Winds picked up ridgetops gusting to strong from the SSW. This pit was adjacent to an avalanche that was skier triggered on January 30, 2024. Pit is representative of weak layer avalanche failed on. Crown face was more like 4-7' deep, 150' wide running 800' vertical feet. Crown face was hard slab 1f+ isolated to a rocky steep gully feature. Photos below show deeper crown face. Pit location was on skiers right side of upper crown in a lower angle area.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Surprising series of crusts and facets. Hard to keep track of which crusts belong to which warming events. 1cm Facet Layer sandwiched between two hard crusts appears to be layer of concern, with loading could become a problem.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Collapsing, localized;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Pit dug near Cross Mtn TH Parking. The top .5 cm of snow had surface hoar on a sun crust with faceted crystals growing on the bottom side of the sun crust. I called out just the melt forms of the sun crust in the top layer.
Also, as my partner stepped into the pit to help isolate the PST column, a weak layer collapsed in the area and I saw it shoot thorough the column before it was isolated. I ran the saw below this collapsed layer when I conducted the PST.

Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: After a CTN we removed the top ~60 cm of the column then repeated the CT. This produced a CT23 SC on the FCxr above the Solstice MFcr. When we attempted to pry the block out it failed below this layer at the bottom of the pit with firm pressure. Despite these results demonstrating decent strength, Stevens Pass Patrol triggered multiple D2.5 slides on this layer during the same day with large air blasts.

Variable HS across slope due to wind distribution. Found a relatively thin snowpack with poor structure (4/5 lemons). Despite temps conducive to rounding and increasing hardness of the PWL, tests are still propagating. Strength of the slab is high and is likely difficult to affect weak layer except in thinner areas.
Konvex vid översta delen av trädgränsen.

Melting surface hoar at snow surface at pit location -surface hoar intact as high as 11,954 (top of ballroom) -surface snow getting wet, throwing snowballs downhill formed roller balls -extremely calm, almost no detectable wind -10cm to ground of snowpit, did not appear to be faceted grains, and more closely resembled rounds
OBJ: stabilitetstest i drevsnöflak och testa pwl.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Moist snowpack down to 1/4 interface. Not full snowball moist but close. December facets were dry. ECTX but then propagated on 2 more hard taps at 1/4 interface.

Mostly sunny today and 40's F at 6000. Last 3 days ~.2 - .25" of rain at all elevations. Entire snowpack at 0C. ECTP in 2 of the 3 tests here, right under 12/7 rain crust. Crusts are breaking down. Found similar overall snowpack structure and 11/24 SH faintly on S aspect pit at 6000'.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Collapsing, localized; Cracking;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Snowpack was slightly moist throughout, likely from rainfall over the previous 24h. Decomposing noncontinuous MFcrs were found at the interfaces between layers down 39 and down 58. Isothermic midpack made for difficult skiing. Of note, a previously suspect layer showed no results during CTs, however, during ECT it failed as ECTN11 down 39 on the FC layer below.
Ca 600m ifrån Ma2,5 från v. 4.
This was a Test pit I Did not dig all the way to the ground

Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Pit dug in a flat spot, so not representative, but the combination of layers could signify a problem in steeper and wind-drifted spots higher up the mountain - a few icy crusts, a few layers with some faceted crystals, large differences in hardness between adjacent layers...
No avalanches or signs of instability noticed - but we were very far away from any real avalanche terrain
Generally strengthening from last month, mid-pack quite stout. Crust breaking down, facets all rounding

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Пълен профил на полигон за наблюдения с цел проследяване на промените в снежната покривка на редовни интервали. Сравнително хомогенна снежна покривка. Открояват се 2 ледени кори: 1-та е в долната част от декември, втората е почти на повърхноста от дъждовете на 18.01. Между двете е плътен слой от закръглени кристали, които поради плитката снежна покривка и ниски температури, са започнали да фасетират. В този слой се открояват два интерфейса от по-едри фасети, които при тестове за стабилност на равно не дават резултат, но е възможно в преходния пояс на стръмни склонове да реагират.
ECT not isolated below 30cm

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; We skied slope;
Collapsing, localized; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Had one large whumpf while leaving the pit location.

4-6" of new light density snow ontop of supportable. Greybird most of the day and the sun had no impact on the surface snow. Good skiing on all aspects. Below 7K you feel this zipper MF crust but it also skied fine. I observed several natural avalanches looking across the terrain. They all were in steeper lower terrain.

Test Pit on Wild West Traverse, left side of slope above corner. 1990m. 25°. HS 250cm.
Snow was right side up with a 1mm rime crust ↓ 7cm.
ECTN 17, CTM 12, 13 (RP) ↓ 25cm on DFs 1-2mm (2/2) CTH 26 (RP) ↓ 40cm on DFs 0.5-1mm (1/2) CTH 26 (SP) ↓ 50cm on DFs 1-2 (1/2)

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: 20 yds down from the ridge line, just above the convexity skiers R of the goal posts in hanky panky

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug a quick and dirty pit in the middle of our most skier compacted slide path to evaluated how explosives, skier traffic and the recent warm weather have effected our two PWLs - the January 4 crust/facet combo and the Early Season basal facets. This path avalanched on the January 4 crust/facet layer during the recent avalanche cycle on or about 2024-01-11. Unfortunately the natural avalanche cycle didn't step down in to the basal facets and the crust/facet layer was loaded with additional snow prior to breaking down. Thus poor structure still exists within our skier compacted terrrain.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized;
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Attempted to dig a pit in an untracked portion of our avalanche terrain to observe a verify our two PWLs - basal facets and crust/facet combo. Pit was dug below the elevation of the January 4 rain line. Both PWLs still exist but are showing signs of strengthening with rounding beginning to take place and moist grains.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug 200' away on the same slope as an avalanche that occurred in last 3-6 days. R3-D2, 1-2' deep, 150' wide. Cracking around our sled tracks on this slope and as we approached pit. Upper layer of surface likely collapsed prior to digging/testing.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Beautiful day in the mountains with 4" new. First day without glaring signs of instability since around Jan 12. No collapsing, higher scores on ECT's, and a denser December drought layer.

Weekly full profile, specific goals to see propagation propensity and reactivity of recent storm snow. Results show some reactivity and propagation propensity in the December 23rd layer, some reactivity on Jan 1st layer in column tests but no propagations on ECTs on that layer
